So after holding four public meetings and picking apart the ethical nuances, the commission is releasing its conclusions.
We concluded that the federal government would have to take multiple steps before anthrax vaccine trials with children could be ethically considered.
It would not be ethical to do it today.
The first thing that would have to be done would be a lot more research - research that convincingly shows kids would face no more than what's considered minimal risk.
Minimal risk being a level that a child routinely encounters in daily life or a medical checkup that poses absolutely no substantial risk or threat to the child.
So researchers should first try testing the vaccine in younger adults.
If that goes OK, they might try it on the oldest kids and then work their way down very slowly to the youngest.
Other experts praise the commission's conclusions, like Lawrence Gostin of Georgetown University.
We can overreact to the threat of bioterrorism and other kinds of terrorist attacks when we really don't know whether when or if we will get any kind of an attack.
It seems to me that we really do need to have very rigorous ethical safeguards.
But those pushing for the testing, like Fagbuyi, worry what might happen if there's an attack in the meantime.

During the time of an emergency, when there's enough chaos going on and discord, is that the time we really want to be explaining that, well, we don't have all the evidence at this time and we could have done this earlier and we did not?

Officials at the Department of Health and Human Services say they will review the commission's report before making a decision about whether or how to proceed with testing the anthrax vaccine in children.
